content.question: The graph above shows the polar curves <math alttext="r equals, 3 plus cosine theta, minus the sine of, open parenthesis, 2 theta, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="r equals, 1 plus sine theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the area bounded between the two polar curves?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.9: (BC ONLY) Finding the Area of the Region Bounded by Two Polar Curves

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
